;选举;;欧洲议会;;看到极右翼总体上取得了最大的进展，尽管代表中右翼的欧洲人民党和中间的社会党和民主党-左翼，仍然是最大的投票集团。绿党失去了四分之一的席位。在;法国;，玛丽娜·勒庞的右翼全国集会获得了三分之一的选票，是埃马纽埃尔·马克龙领导的复兴党的两倍多。法国总统出人意料地宣布解散国民议会并要求提前举行选举。马克龙先生在 2022 年失去了议会多数席位，并表示该国现在“需要平静与和谐的明显多数”。

;

;;德国执政联盟在选举中也遭到猛烈抨击。反对党基督教民主党位居第一，民族主义的德国另类选择党（<小>;A;f<小>;D;）位居第二，击败了政府中的所有三个政党。德国总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨 (Olaf Scholz) 所在的社会民主党仅获得 14% 的支持率，这是全国民调中有史以来最差的表现。 ;A;f;D;的支持率增长幅度最大的是 16-24 岁的人群，这是 16 岁青少年首次能够投票的选举。

;
; https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2024/06/13/politics /内容/jh8dau6t4peab8jo0p0thma3442pq0gq Thu, 13 Jun 2024 13:55:41 GMT 商业
;;;;
;;

;;;美联储;;将基准利率维持在 5.25% 至 5.5% 的范围内。市场对其降息道路上的最新举措更感兴趣。美联储现在认为今年只会降息一次，最迟可能在 12 月降息，这与 3 月份预测的三次降息相比有很大变化。 6 月 6 日，;欧洲央行;五年来首次降息，将存款利率削减四分之一个百分点，至 3.75%。

;

;美国劳动力市场 ;再次出乎意料;，5 月份新增 272,000 个;就业岗位;，远高于分析师的预测，也是今年就业人数第二高的月度增幅。年;通货膨胀;率降至3.3%。

;; https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2024/06/13/business /内容/h4db5vltp3llavem8drfcf8fq5b3u20l Thu, 13 Jun 2024 13:55:38 GMT KAL的卡通
;;
;;

;;深入探讨本周漫画的主题：;

;

;;法国极右翼在欧盟选举中获胜，马克龙呼吁提前投票;（2024 年 6 月 10 日）;
;欧洲峰值已满 25 周年：为什么 1999 年 6 月标志着欧洲大陆的顶峰< /a>;（2024 年 6 月 6 日）;
;欧洲各地的极右翼势力越来越接近权力;（2023 年 9 月 14 日）

; https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2024/06/13/kals-cartoon /内容/ak36mprmurr3hg09mslnb3cvi5fgpmcr Thu, 13 Jun 2024 13:55:35 GMT 本周封面;;;;;

; ;这周;我们在全球范围内报道了中国科学的崛起和崛起。

;

;西方理解得太慢了中国现在正在生产一些世界上最好的研究和创新。 2003年，美国发表的高影响力科学论文是中国的20倍。到 2022 年，中国已超过美国和欧盟。 2014年推出《自然》著名期刊文章贡献指数时，中国的得分还不到美国的三分之一。到 2023 年，这一数字已达到顶峰。根据莱顿科学研究成果量的排名，世界上十所大学包括六所中国。

;
; https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2024/06/13/this-weeks-cover /content/o143ls1ihgr7v7me5cs9pmondku276pm Thu, 13 Jun 2024 11:38:09 GMT KAL的卡通<部分class =“ CSS-1UGVD2U E18WK22U0”>; <样式data-emotion =“ CSS J0A8MG”>;。css-j0a8mg img {display：block;}。css-j0a8mg .egmy3ck2样式>; ; ;; ; ; ;

;In a surprise shake-up of ;Russia's; security apparatus, Vladimir Putin moved ;Sergei Shoigu; from his job as minister of defence, a role he has held since 2012, to the national security council. His replacement is Andrei Belousov, an economist with no experience of security matters but who has worked extensively on military budgets. The changing of the guard will have little effect on operations in Ukraine. Mr Putin prefers to speak directly to Valery Gerasimov, his senior general in the field. Mr Belousov said his task was to achieve victory, but “with minimal human losses”, presumably just on the Russian side.

;

;Mr Putin met his Chinese counterpart, ;;Xi Jinping;;, in Beijing. It was his first trip abroad since winning a sham election in March. The leaders reaffirmed their support for each other. Mr Xi has been accused by Western officials of propping up Mr Putin's war machine in Ukraine.

;
; https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2024/05/16/politics /content/gid4ipv2gmmkeoap4c6471tm50546oqh Thu, 16 May 2024 13:32:44 GMT 商业
;;;
;;
;;

;Joe Biden imposed another round of tariffs on Chinese exports to America, most notably increasing the duties on ;;electric vehicles;; to 100%. America imports relatively few Chinese ;EV;s but Mr Biden suggested his steps were pre-emptive. Chinese carmakers are expanding in Europe, but “We're not going to let China flood our market,” said the president, with one eye on votes in Michigan, the centre of America's car industry and a crucial state in November's election. Tariffs are also going up on semiconductors, solar cells and critical minerals. A furious China described the decision as “political manipulation” and vowed to retaliate.

;

;;Anglo American; decided to break up its business to fend off a revised takeover bid from ;;BHP;,; ;;valued at £34bn ($43bn). Anglo will divest its coking coal assets and spin off its platinum and De Beers diamonds divisions. It is also considering the options for its nickel business in order to focus on copper, iron ore and crop nutrients. The mining giant's headquarters are in London but it employs 45,000 people in South Africa, where it was founded in 1917; the government there will want a say in any demerger or sale process.

;
; https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2024/05/16/business /content/t2aep72pivkdci7ov71fjr912dn36jtf Thu, 16 May 2024 13:32:44 GMT This week's cover
;;;
;;
;;

;From the May 18th 2024 edition

;;

;Discover stories from this section and more在内容列表中

;;;Explore the edition;;
;;
;;

;;I;;F you come ;from a generation that witnessed the collapse of communism and the triumph of Western democracy, it may be hard to fathom how we could be posing the question that features on this week's cover. And yet Americans have heard their own leaders denounce the integrity of their democracy. They have seen fellow citizens try to block the transfer of power from one administration to the next. Over the past quarter-century, feckless war-making, a financial crisis and institutional rot have let loose a ferocity in America's politics that has given presidential contests seemingly existential stakes.

;

;The word “dictator” conjures up the 20th century's worst despots. We could have played on that association, with a generalissimo's peaked cap and a “;USA;” badge, or a Nuremberg rally on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial.

;
; https://www.economist.com/the-world-this-week/2024/05/16/this-weeks-cover /content/4u2emkgrbcsin3lf97jfghiou4qk04gd Thu, 16 May 2024 13:13:12 GMT美国 政治
;;;

;;

;For the first time in five years, ;;Xi Jinping; visited Europe;. China's leader was welcomed by his French counterpart, Emmanuel Macron, who pressed him to help end the war in Ukraine and to establish a more balanced trade relationship. Mr Xi gave little ground. He then moved on to Serbia, where he commemorated the 25th anniversary of America's bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade. “This we should never forget,” he wrote in a piece for a Serbian newspaper. Mr Xi wrapped up his tour in Hungary, a member of the ;EU; and ;NATO; that is also a staunch supporter of China. Mr Xi praised its “independent” foreign policy.

;

;;Israel; carried out ;air strikes on Rafah; in southern ;Gaza; and told 100,000 civilians to leave because it was planning to “operate” there. It took control of part of the Philadelphi corridor, a strip of land next to Egypt, as well as the Rafah crossing on the border with Egypt. Joe Biden said he would not supply Israel with the weapons that would be used in an attack on Rafah. Meanwhile, Israel temporarily closed Kerem Shalom, a commercial crossing into Gaza through which most humanitarian aid enters the strip, after four soldiers were killed in a rocket attack by Hamas.
